Comprehensive Risk Adjustment Features and Benefits
Comprehensive Risk Adjustment
Features and Benefits

• Site-of-service neutral
• Site-of-service neutral

– incentives to hospitalize are minimized • Health status conveys most of the dollars
– incentives to hospitalize are minimized
• Health status conveys most of the dollars

– less weight is applied to demographic factors
– less weight is applied to demographic factors

• Payment accuracy and fairness is improved • overall explained variability • predictive ratios for biased groups
• Payment accuracy and fairness is improved
• overall explained variability
• predictive ratios for biased groups

Hierarchical Co-Existing Conditions (HCC’s)
Hierarchical Co-Existing Conditions
(HCC’s)

• Diagnoses are grouped into 543 DxGroups • DxGroups are then sorted using cost and clinical
• Diagnoses are grouped into 543 DxGroups
• DxGroups are then sorted using cost and clinical

criteria into 134 HCC groups based on ICD-9 codes
criteria into 134 HCC groups based on ICD-9 codes

• 75 HCCs are used • Hierarchical; e.g., 8 levels of cancer, 3 levels of
• 75 HCCs are used

diabetes
diabetes

• Additive across types of diseases: A person may be

“assigned” to multiple groups

Ambulatory Diagnosis Groups - Hospital Dominant (ADG-HOSDOM)
Ambulatory Diagnosis Groups - Hospital
Dominant (ADG-HOSDOM)

• Diagnoses are grouped into 32 ADGs based on:
• Diagnoses are grouped into 32 ADGs based on:

– duration of the condition(acute, recurrent, or chronic) – severity of the condition (minor/stable vs major/unstable) – diagnostic certainty (symptoms vs documented diseases) – etiology of the condition (infectious, injury, or other) – specialty care involvement (medical, surgical, etc.)
– duration of the condition(acute, recurrent, or chronic)
– severity of the condition (minor/stable vs major/unstable)
– diagnostic certainty (symptoms vs documented diseases)
– etiology of the condition (infectious, injury, or other)
– specialty care involvement (medical, surgical, etc.)

• 13 ADGs were selected for the Medicare model • HOSDOM marker is comprised of diagnoses that have at least a 50 % probability of leading to a hospitalization.
• 13 ADGs were selected for the Medicare model
• HOSDOM marker is comprised of diagnoses that
have at least a 50 % probability of leading to a
hospitalization.

Chronic Illness and Disability Payment System (CDPS)
Chronic Illness and Disability Payment
System (CDPS)

• The CDPS model includes 20 major categories of
• The CDPS model includes 20 major categories of

diagnoses, grouped by body system or type of clinical diagnosis. – Examples of body system categories are:
diagnoses, grouped by body system or type of clinical
diagnosis.
– Examples of body system categories are:

cardiovascular, skeletal and connective, and pulmonary
cardiovascular, skeletal and connective, and pulmonary

– Examples of clinical diagnosis-based categories are
– Examples of clinical diagnosis-based categories are

diabetes, cancer and infectious disease.
diabetes, cancer and infectious disease.

• The 20 major categories are further divided by cost levels
• The 20 major categories are further divided by cost levels

(generally high, medium and low cost). Individuals can be assigned to multiple categories.
(generally high, medium and low cost).
Individuals can be assigned to multiple categories.

Office of Strategic Planning HCFA, 3/15/00
Office of Strategic Planning
HCFA, 3/15/00

Clinically Detailed Risk Information System for Cost (CD-RISC)
Clinically Detailed Risk Information
System for Cost (CD-RISC)

• The CD-RISC model has 173 groupings of conditions,
• The CD-RISC model has 173 groupings of conditions,

each with up to 3 severity levels . – Severity is assigned based on ICD-9 diagnosis codes, in
each with up to 3 severity levels .
– Severity is assigned based on ICD-9 diagnosis codes, in

combination with codes for complications or comorbidities.
combination with codes for complications or comorbidities.

• The groups are then organized into hierarchies within 16
• The groups are then organized into hierarchies within 16

body systems, e.g. circulatory, digestive, neoplasm, infections, mental.
body systems, e.g. circulatory, digestive, neoplasm,
infections, mental.

• Individuals are assigned to the highest level in each body
• Individuals are assigned to the highest level in each body

system. The model is additive across body systems.
system. The model is additive across body systems.

Office of Strategic Planning
HCFA, 3/15/00

Clinical Risk Groups (CRGs)
Clinical Risk Groups (CRGs)

• Diagnoses are assigned to 31 Major Diagnostic
• Diagnoses are assigned to 31 Major Diagnostic

Categories (MDCs) corresponding to a single organ system or etiology.
Categories (MDCs) corresponding to a single organ
system or etiology.

• Each MDC is subdivided into Episode Diagnostic
• Each MDC is subdivided into Episode Diagnostic

Categories (EDCs). – EDCs are classified into 6 levels: Dominant Chronic,
Categories (EDCs).
– EDCs are classified into 6 levels: Dominant Chronic,

Moderate Chronic, Minor Chronic, Chronic Manifestation, Significant Acute, and Minor Acute.
Moderate Chronic, Minor Chronic, Chronic
Manifestation, Significant Acute, and Minor Acute.

– Individuals can be assigned multiple EDCs in an
– Individuals can be assigned multiple EDCs in an

MDC. (533 EDCs across the 31 MDCs)
MDC. (533 EDCs across the 31 MDCs)

Office of Strategic Planning HCFA, 3/15/00
Office of Strategic Planning
HCFA, 3/15/00

Clinical Risk Groups (CRGs)
Clinical Risk Groups (CRGs)

• In each MDC, a person’s most significant EDC is designated as the Primary Chronic Disease (PCD).
• In each MDC, a person’s most significant EDC is
designated as the Primary Chronic Disease (PCD).

• The PCD in each MDC is assigned a severity
• The PCD in each MDC is assigned a severity

level, based on: – presence of other chronic EDCs within the
level, based on:
– presence of other chronic EDCs within the

same MDC and across other MDCs, presence of acute EDCs from any MDC, and past treatment history.
same MDC and across other MDCs, presence
of acute EDCs from any MDC, and past
treatment history.

Office of Strategic Planning HCFA, 3/15/00
Office of Strategic Planning
HCFA, 3/15/00

Clinical Risk Groups (CRGs)
Clinical Risk Groups (CRGs)

• Combinations of diseases across MDCs are classified
• Combinations of diseases across MDCs are classified

into groups called statuses.
into groups called statuses.

• There are 9 statuses, e.g., Dominant Chronic Diseases
• There are 9 statuses, e.g., Dominant Chronic Diseases • T h e r e

Selecting a Comprehensive Model
Selecting a Comprehensive Model

• Conceptual: Does the model make sense to
• Conceptual: Does the model make sense to

clinicians, providers, and plans? • Comparative analytic performance:
clinicians, providers, and plans?
• Comparative analytic performance:

– accuracy in predicting individual expenditures? – accuracy in predicting for biased groups? • Incentives and appropriateness for payment
– accuracy in predicting individual expenditures?
– accuracy in predicting for biased groups?
• Incentives and appropriateness for payment

applications: Sensitivity to coding variability? • Administrative feasibility: Data requirements?
applications: Sensitivity to coding variability?
